Abstract
Electroactive polymer composites are interesting materials for advance technological
applications due to the possibility to combine the electroactive properties of the polymer
matrix with a large variety of fillers that allow tailored responses for specific
applications.
The best all-around electroactive polymers are poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) and its
copolymers which allied with the properties of porous zeolite materials, with tailored
shape, size and Si/Al ratio, among others, leads to the possibility of development of
promising PVDF/zeolite composites.
In this way, a study of the structural, thermal and electrical properties of PVDF
composites prepared with different framework zeolite types (LTL, LTA, FAU and
MFI), different polymer solvents (DMF, DMSO, TEP) and different zeolite (NaY)
concentrations (4, 16, 24 and 32 wt %) was performed.
Further, the dielectric response, electrical conductivity and electric modulus of the
composites were investigated as a function of NaYzeolite content. The zeolite influence
on the electroactive ?-phase crystallization of PVDF was explored, as well as the effect
of clay layered structure (Montmorillonite, Kaolinite and Laponite) on the electroactive
?-phase nucleation and on the optical transparency of the composite.
It was found that the obtained composites showed an electrical response dependence on
the pore structure and chemical content of the inorganic host. The dielectric response of
the composites is directly related to the Si/Al ratio, leading zeolites with lower Si/Al
ratios to larger dielectric responses and encapsulation efficiencies in the composites. It
was also found that the zeolite content strongly influences the macroscopic response of
dielectric response, which increases for increasing filler content. The dielectric constant
at room temperature reaches values larger than 1000 for the 32 wt.% composite at 1 kHz
what is mainly attributed to restricted ion mobility and interfacial polarization effects
due to the zeolite inclusion, leading also to high dielectric losses. For the higher zeolite
concentrations the composite d.c. electrical conductivity is characterized by two
conducting regimes separated by a concentration independent breaking voltage of 4 V,
which is associated to an intrazeolite charge transport.
vi Ana Catarina Lopes
Dielectric relaxation studies show that the main relaxation process (?-relaxation) of the
amorphous phase of the polymer matrix is not affected by the presence of the zeolite
and, in a similar way, the zeolite low temperature relaxation is not significantly affected
by the polymer phase. On the other hand, the electric modulus formalism reveals
significant contributions of the fillers to the electrical permittivity and conductivity of
the composites. The presence of the zeolite particles increases a.c. conductivity and the
Maxwell-Wagner-Sillars contribution that is predominant at low frequencies with
respect to the ohmic contribution to permittivity.
The ability of zeolites to induce the eletroactive ?-phase nucleation of PVDF is directly
dependent on the Si/Al ratio and zeolite content; however it only occurs when the
composite is melted at temperatures below 200 ºC. The complete ?-phase crystallization
of the polymer crystalline phase occurs for a filler content of 16 wt% of LTA or FAU
zeolite structure.
The even higher surface interaction of clays when exfoliated leads to the same
phenomenon with an amount of 0.50 % of Montmorillonite clay content. The
electroactivity of the material has been proven by measuring the piezoelectric d33
response of the material, which presents a value of ?7 pC/N, lower than for ?-PVDF
obtained by mechanical stretching but still among the largest coefficients obtained for
polymers. Further, the optical transmittance in the visible range is strongly enhanced
with respect to the transmittance of the pure polymer.
The development, characterization and physical-chemical understanding of these
PVDF/zeolite and PVDF/clay composites resulted in suitable materials for applications
in diverse areas including battery separator membranes and biomedical applications.

Resumo
Os compósitos poliméricos electroativos são materiais muito interessantes para
aplicações tecnológicas devido à possibilidade de combinar as propriedades
electroativas da matriz polimérica com uma larga variedade de materiais que deste
modo permitem a manipulação das suas respostas para as fazer adequadas a aplicações
específicas.
De entre os poucos polímeros electroativos, as melhores respostas são obtidas no
poli(fluoreto de vinilideno) (PVDF) e nos seus copolímeros que, aliados às propriedades
dos materiais porosos de zeólitos, com forma, tamanho e razão Si/Al modificáveis, entre
outras características, leva à possibilidade de desenvolver compósitos promissores de
PVDF/zeólitos.
Deste modo, foi efetuado um estudo das propriedades estruturais, térmicas e elétricas
dos compósitos de PVDF preparados com diferentes tipos de zeólitos (LTL, LTA, FAU
e MFI), diferentes solventes do polímero (DMF, DMSO, TEP) e diferentes
concentrações de zeólito (NaY) (4, 16, 24 e 32 % em peso).
Foi ainda investigada a resposta dielétrica, condutividade eléctrica e modulo elétrico dos
compósitos em função da concentração do zeólito NaY. A influência do zeólito na
cristalização da fase electroativa ? do PVDF foi explorada, bem como o efeito da
estrutura lamelar das argilas (Montmorillonite, Kaolinite e Laponite) na nucleação da
fase-? e na transparência ótica do compósito.
Descobriu-se que os compósitos obtidos exibiam uma resposta elétrica dependente da
estrutura porosa e da composição química dos compostos inorgânicos encapsulados. A
resposta dielétrica dos compósitos está diretamente relacionada com a razão Si/Al,
levando a que os zeólitos com uma baixa razão Si/Al apresentem elevadas respostas
dielétricas e maior eficiência de encapsulamento no compósito. Foi também descoberto
que o teor de zeólito influencia fortemente a resposta dielétrica macroscópica,
aumentando com a concentração de zeólitos no compósito. A constante dielétrica à
temperatura ambiente atinge valores superiores a 1000 para o compósito com 32 % em
peso de NaY a 1kHz, o que é atribuído principalmente à mobilidade iónica restrita e a
efeitos de polarização interfacial devido à inclusão de zeólito, levando também a
grandes perdas dielétricas. Para concentrações de zeólito elevada, a condutividade
viii Ana Catarina Lopes
elétrica d.c. do compósito é caracterizada por dois regimes de condutividade separados
por um potencial de disrupção de 4 V, independente da concentração, que está
associado ao transporte de carga intrazeólito.
Estudos de relaxação dielétrica mostram que o processo de relaxação ? da fase amorfa
da matriz polimérica não é afetada pela presença do zeólito e, de um modo semelhante,
a relaxação de baixa temperatura do zeólito não é afetada significativamente pela
presença da fase polimérica. Por outro lado, o formalismo do modulo elétrico revela
contributos relevantes das inclusões para a permitividade elétrica e condutividade dos
compósitos. A presença das partículas de zeólito aumenta a condutividade a.c. e a
contribuição Maxwell-Wagner-Sillars que predomina a baixas frequências
relativamente à contribuição ohmica para a permitividade.
A capacidade dos zeólitos induzirem a nucleação da fase eletroativa ? do PVDF
depende diretamente da razão Si/Al e da quantidade de zeólito; contudo, apenas se
verifica quando o compósito é fundido a temperaturas inferiores a 200 ºC. A
cristalização completa em fase ? pode ocorrer para uma concentração de 16% das
estruturas de zeólito LTA ou FAU.
A ainda maior superfície de interacção das argilas, quando exfoliadas, resulta no mesmo
fenómeno com uma concentração de 0.5% de argila Montmorillonite. A eletroatividade
do material foi comprovada através da medição da resposta piezoelétrica d33 do
material, que apresenta um valor de –7 pC/N, mais baixo do que o de ?-PVDF obtido
por estiramento mecânico mas ainda entre os maiores coeficientes piezoelétricos obtidos
para polímeros. Mais ainda, a transmitância ótica na gama visível é fortemente
melhorada relativamente à transmitância do polímero puro.
O desenvolvimento, caracterização e compreensão físico-química destes compósitos
PVDF/zeólito e PVDF/argila resultou em materiais adequados para aplicações em áreas
diversas que incluem membranas para baterias e aplicações biomédicas.

1.1. Electroactive polymers
Electroactive polymers are one of the most interesting classes of polymers used as smart
materials. Its ability to respond to an electrical stimulation with large displacement
makes them appropriate for the use in an increasing number of applications including
sensors, actuators, energy harvesting and as biomaterials in the biomedical field, among
others [1, 2] Piezo, pyro and ferroelectricity are three of its more important properties.
Piezoelectricity consists on the variation of the polarization of the material when
mechanically stressed or on the development of a mechanical strain when an electric
field is applied. Pyroelectricity consists on the variation of the polarization of the
material as a response to a variation of temperature. Finally ferroelectricity corresponds
to the characteristic of the material of having stable polarization that can be hysterically
switched by an electric field [3].
Although the piezoelectric and pyroelectric coefficients of polymers are generally lower
than those of ceramic and single crystals, polymer and polymer based composites have
advantages for specific applications related to their low permittivity, low thermal
conductivity, softness and flexibility, good impedance matching to air and water and
relatively low cost.
Among the few polymers presenting piezo, pyro or ferroelectricity, such as Nylon–11
[4], PLLA [5] and PLGA [6], Poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) and its copolymers
have the best all-around electroactive properties, being therefore the polymer of choice
for an increasing number of applications [7, 8].

1.3. Poly(vinylidene fluoride) composites
Despite the interesting electroactive and mechanical properties of PVDF, ideal for the
demands of novel technological applications that includes flexible, simple fabricated
and easy shaped smart materials, this polymer still present a much low piezoelectric
response when compared with materials such as lead zirconate titanate (PZT) and
barium BaTiO3 [31]. In order to bring added value and to improve its performance, the
combination of PVDF polymer with suitable fillers has been pursued.
For improving the electroactive response of PVDF, materials displaying high
piezoelectricity and ferroelectric properties have been incorporated in the polymer.
Simultaneously, the combination of the polymer matrix with the filler, either due to the
high dielectric constant of the filler or by surface effects and matrix-filler interactions
leads to the increase of dielectric properties that, in turn, improves the energy density of
the composite when compared to the neat polymer. When compared to the conventional
dielectric materials, such as ceramics and single crystals, polymer composites present
high mechanical flexibility and ability to be molded on the desired shapes [32].
PZT, a ceramic with high piezoelectric coefficient and dielectric constant and low
dielectric and mechanical loses was added to PVDF polymer and the results shows a
composite with an increase of almost 10 times in the dielectric constant when compared
with the pure polymer [33]. Results obtained with the introduction of other ceramics
such as BaTiO3 as well as Pb(Mg1/3Nb2/3)O3-PbTiO3 (PMN-PT) point in the same
direction [34, 35]. Further, BaTiO3 can stimulate the nucleation of the electroactive
phase of PVDF, reaching ?-phase fractions up to 82% [20]. However, despite the
increase of dielectric constant, the ceramic loading deteriorates the mechanical qualities
of the composite and prevents its use in many technological applications.
Metal nanoparticles have been also introduced in the polymer matrix. The metal
introduction causes an increase of the dielectric constant due the interfacial polarization
phenomena due to collective oscillation of nanoparticles electrons called surface
plasmon resonances (SPR). This effect is detected even for small loadings of
nanoparticles by an increase of many orders of magnitude of the optical absorption
spectra of the materials, that in turn is dependent on polymer and nanoparticle types, as
well as nanoparticles size, shape, distribution and orientation [36, 37]. In this way, the
introduction of Ag nanoparticles in PVDF lead to an increase of the dielectric constant

1.4. Aluminosilicates
1.4.1. Layered aluminosilicates
Clays are layered aluminosilicated formed by the arrangement of two different sheets:
one consists on tetrahedral SiO4 units, where each Si atom shares one of its O atoms
with a second sheet which in turn consists on aluminiun in octahedral co-ordination
represented as AlO6. There are two different sheets structures. The 1:1 structure consists
on an octahedral sheet, that is held to other sheet by hydrogen bonding that holds the
sheets tightly together, fact that stops the insertion of water molecules or ions between
the sheets and hinders the expansion of the material when it is wet [48] (Figure 1.3 a).
On the other hand, on the 2:1 structure, one AlO6 octahedral sheet is sandwiched
between two AlO4 tetrahedral sheets by covalent bonding. This layer structure can
present an expanding (Figure 1.3 b) or non-expanding lattice (Figure 1.3 c). In some
clay, there is a considerable substitution of aluminum by silicon that can go up to 15 %.
Further, magnesium and iron can also substitute aluminum in the octahedral sheet.
These substitutions create an overall negative charge on the layers that is balanced by
water molecules and ions such as K + , Ca
2+ and Mg
2+ , providing the layered
aluminosilicates of ion exchange capacity [48, 49]. Water and ions hold layers together
by relatively weak forces, allowing the water and other polar molecules to enter
between the unit layers what, in turn, causes the expansion of the lattice [50]. On the
other hand, in some clays the interlayer cation is potassium, which size, charge and
coordination number allows it to fit snugly in the hexagonal rings of oxygens of the two
adjacent silica tetrahedral sheets. This fact results in a strong interlocking ionic bond,
keeping the layers together and precluding water molecules to occupy the interlayer
position[49].

1.4.2. Three-dimensional aluminosilicates
Different fromthe clay layered structure, zeolites consist on three-dimensional
framework structures (Figure 1.4) formed by the combination of TO4 tetrahedra (T = Si,
Al) linked to each other by sharing all the oxygen atoms, forming uniform and
molecular-sized pores and channels. In a silica structure all T of the TO4 tetrahedra
corresponds to Si atoms and the solid is uncharged. However, when a silicon atom is
replaced by an aluminum atom, the electronic relationship between (SiO2)2 and
[AlSiO4] - leads the framework to become negatively charged and requires the balance of
an extra-framework cations within the structure to ensure overall framework neutrality
[61]. This variation from a pure-silica zeolite to a low-silica zeolite transforms an
hydrophobic, acid stable and no ion exchange capacity material into an hydrophilic, acid
soluble and high ion exchange capacity one [62].

molecules. However, this is dependent on the pore diameter of the zeolite largest

that limits it [64]. In this way, conventionally, channel sizesare classified in ultra large,
large, medium or small pore material when they are formed by >12, 12, 10 or 8 member
rings, respectively, resulting in diameter variations between 5 and 20 [64].

required to generate mesoporosity do not generally favor the formation of a crystalline

2.1. Introdution
The combination of polymers with a large variety of fillers has been used to tailor the
macroscopic response of materials towards specific goals for applications [1, 2].
Poly(vinylidene fluoride), PVDF, has been widely used for advanced technological
applications due to its pyro- and piezoelectric properties [3], that makes it suitable for
sensors and actuators, among others [4]. Among the different fillers that can be
incorporated into PVDF in order to tailor mechanical, thermal and electrical response of
the material, are the zeolites, particles with a a rigid three-dimensional framework of
tetrahedral and
primary building units, forming channels and cavities
with sizes in the range of molecular dimensions. Zeolites can entrap molecules allowing
their diffusion, adsorption and reaction within the channel system [5]. In addition to
well defined pores of precise and uniform size, zeolite structures generally show an
excess of negative charge that is compensated by cations which exist within the cages
and channels. These characteristics have lead zeolites to be used in applications such as
catalytic cracking [6], drug delivery systems [7], membranes [8], gas sensors [9], host-
guest antenna material [10], etc.
With respect to the investigation on PVDF/zeolite composites, it has been mainly
focused on the development of filtration or ionic conductivity membranes for fuel cell
applications [11]. However, it has been shown that the presence of NaY zeolite with a
faujasite structure on the PVDF matrix gives origin to many others yet unexplored
possibilities. For example, the presence of NaY in the polymer matrix induces the
crystallization of the polymer in one of its electroactive phases [12], avoiding additional
processing steps as stretching or application of high electric fields in order to obtain the
electroactive phase and allowing therefore miniaturization and incorporation into
microelectronic systems. Further, it was also shown that the inclusion of zeolite fillers
also modifies the electrical behaviour of the composite [13, 14]. The dielectric constant
increases with respect to the pure polymer, fact that is dependent on the number of
cations in the zeolite structure as well as from the molecules encapsulated in the zeolite
cavities [13] as well as on the zeolite content [14]. In addition, the overall electrical
conductivity of the composites is also increased due to intrazeolite charge transport [12,
14]. Due to these developments and the large application potential of PVDF/zeolite
composites, it is necessary to investigate the effect of different zeolites structures with

Y, L, A and ZSM-5 were synthesized and used for the production of PVDF composites

better tailor materials properties for specific applications.
2.2. Experimental
Zeolite Y was prepared by dissolving 0.5 g of Na2SiO3 (Aldrich) and 0.1 g of Al(O-i-
Pr)3 (Aldrich) in 20 g of distilled water. The crystallization was carried out at 95 o C for
24 h. Zeolite A was prepared as follows: 0.5 g of Al (Aldrich) was dissolved in alkaline
solution of 1 g NaOH and 10 g of distilled water. Subsequently, 1g of SiO2 dissolved in
a solution of 1g of NaOH and 10g of distilled water was added. The obtained gel was
homogenized and heated at 90 o C for 24 h. The initial batch for the synthesis of zeolite
L was prepared by dissolving 1.5 g of Al2(SO4)2 (Aldrich) in a solution of 3.61 g of
KOH and 35 g of distilled water and adding 9.05 g of SiO2 (Ludox) and 15.5 g distilled

The influence of zeolites on the modification of the crystallization phase of the polymer
indicates strong polymer-zeolite interactions. Further, the zeolite ability for molecule
encapsulation in its chanels and cavities can also affect the composite electrical
behavior. In this way, thermogravimetric analyses are relevant to further study these
issues. Figure 2.3 shows the weight loss of pristine ?-PVDF and the different

2.3.4. Electrical Response
It has been demonstrated that the introduction of zeolites on polymers in general and in
PVDF in particular influences the dielectric response of the composites [13, 14]. In this
study, the composites were prepared with zeolites with varying pore size, shape and
Si/Al ratio in order to assess their relative relevance in modifying the electrical response
of the material. Figure 2.4 (a) shows the frequency dependent dielectric constant for the
neat polymer and for the four composites. The frequency dependence is similar for the
composites and for the pure polymer, with the dielectric constant decreasing with
increasing frequency [33], however, the values are higher for the composites, excepting
for the PVDF/ZSM-5 one which shows dielectric constant values similar to the polymer
matrix. This increase of the dielectric constant with the zeolite introduction is ascribed
to two main factors. First, the existence of cations in the zeolite cavities leads to a
confined movement of charges into the zeolite cavities and to an interfacial polarization
effects in the zeolite-polymer interface [34]. The cations, that compensate the charge of
the zeolite framework can become free to move through the zeolite cavities and
channels when the applied electric field is enough to overcome that electrostatic force.
However, the movement of the cations is blocked by the polymer surrounding the
zeolites, reducing the conductivity and creating an induced dipole moment, which in
turn gives rise to higher dielectric constant [13]. Further, the water and solvent molecule
encapsulation within the zeolite cavities also contributes to the dielectric response.
These polar molecules can rotate towards the dielectric field direction and contribute to
the increase of dielectric constant [30, 35]
This interpretation is supported by the dielectric behavior of the composite prepared
with the ZSM-5 zeolite (Figure 2.4) , which does not content aluminous atoms and
therefore has no charge compensation cations in the cavities. Furthermore, the structure
of ZSM-5 is hydrophobic and does not capture solvent and water molecules, when
compared with aluminium containing zeolites. This fact is further supported by the
above discussed TGA results (Figure 2.3). Due to these characteristics, the ZSM-5
zeolite does not contribute to the increase of composite dielectric constant, which
confirms the proposed mechanism for the increase of the dielectric response.
On the contrary, zeolite A is the one that shows the lowest Si/Al ratio and so (Table
2.1), the largest amount of cations in its cavities. This zeolite is also, together with Y
zeolite, able to capture a significant amount of water and solvent molecules (Figure 2.3).

2.4. Conclusion
This work discloses the influence of zeolites L, A, Y and ZSM-5 on the structural,
thermal and electrical properties of PVDF. Zeolites Y and A shoe the ability to nucleate
the electroactive phase of the polymer due to stronger electrostatic interactions related
to larger cation content. Further, the channel microstructure also plays an important role
as the L zeolite is not able to nucleate the ?-phase of the polymer due to a reduced lower
interaction area with the polymer. The solvent and water encapsulation ability is directly
related with the Si/Al ratio and so is the dielectric response of the material: lower Si/Al
ratios promote larger dielectric constants and encapsulation efficiencies. Again, this
response can be additionally refined by the dimensionality of the pore system. Thus,
zeolite L containing 1D channels shows superior performance than the 3D pore system
of zeolite Y.

3.1. Introduction
Polymers are used in a wide variety of applications like structural parts, tissues,
packaging, medical drugs, communications and many others [1, 2]. However, the need
to improve their functional properties without substantial modifications of the
characteristic polymer properties [3] lead to the incorporation of fillers within the
polymer matrix, yielding polymer composites. Among functional polymers for
advanced applications, one of the most interesting ones is poly(vinylidene fluoride)
(PVDF) due to properties like ferroelectricity, piezoelectricity, pyroelectricity [4, 5]
together with flexibility, biocompatibility, a good thermal and chemical resistance [6,
7]. These properties make PVDF interesting for application in the areas of sensor and
actuator. PVDF is a semi-crystalline polymer that can be in four crystalline phases: ?, ?,
? and ?. Each one of them can be obtained by varying processing conditions [8, 9]. For
sensor and actuator applications, ?-phase of PVDF is typically obtained by the
stretching of ?-phase PVDF [10], which is the polymorph obtained in the conventional
extrusion processes. The ?-phase provides the larger piezoelectric and dielectric
response of the pure polymer [11]. PVDF has been widely used in the production of
composites by the incorporation of different fillers. In particular, PVDF/ceramic
composites have been used in order to improve dielectric and piezoelectric response of
the material [11, 12], PVDF/ferrites in order to achieve magnetic or magnetoelectric
response [13, 14], PVDF/clay composites, in order to tailor phase content and improve
optical transparency [15, 16], and PVDF/zeolite composites for modify the overall
electrical response [17], among others.
In particular, zeolite composites show large potential to modify composite response due
both to their surface chemistry, large surface area and intrinsic porous microstructure
[18] allowing to further encapsulate specific molecules within the zeolite cavities [19-
21]. The zeolites are crystalline hydrated aluminosilicates of alkali metals and earth
alkali metals like sodium, calcium, magnesium and potassium. with the empirical
formula M2/nO.Al2O3.xSiO2yH2O [22], where M represents the compensating cation with
valence n, x is a number from 2 to 10 and y is a number from 2 to 7. They are formed
by tetrahedron unit structures, with the [AlO4] -5
tetrahedron presented in [SiO4] -4
structure carrying the negative charge excess. This negative charge should be
compensated by cations which exist within the cages and channels [23-25]. The cations,

together with water molecules, form hydration spheres and compensate the structure.
The ionic exchange performed with cations allows to change the zeolite physical and
chemistry properties such as thermal stability, adsorption capacity and amount and
strength of acidic sites, among others [26]. The zeolite Y belonging to the faujasite
(FAU) family is the one selected for the present work due to previous results where
dielectric response of the PVDF/zeolite composites was improved using ionic
exchanged NaY zeolite [17]. This zeolite is formed by a three dimensional structure
with twelve silicon or aluminium atoms [27], yielding cavities that allows the
incorporation of many different molecules. Some studies have been performed with
zeolites within different polymer in order to improve their physical and chemical
properties [28]. Zeolites have been used to improve the conductivity of polyaniline
(PANI) [28], for gas separation applications on polymer membranes [29, 30]],
heterogeneous catalysis [31, 32], proton exchange membranes for fuel-cells [32, 33] and
for controlled drug release applications [33]. Zeolites are also being used to modify the
phase and electrical response of PVDF [17, 34]. It was shown that the presence of
cations in the zeolites cavities, induce an increase of the dielectric and conductivity
response of the polymer due to restrict ionic motions and to an interfacial polarization
effects [17], useful for a wide range of applications. In these studies it was also
confirmed the encapsulation of water and/or solvent molecules within the zeolite
cavities, contributing to the overall increase in the dielectric response of the composites.
The PVDF composites were prepared by solvent casting, which implies contact of the
zeolite with the polymer solution that can be encapsulated in the zeolite microporous
structure and therefore affect the electrical properties of the zeolites. Solvents like N,N-
dimethylacetamide (DMA), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), dimethylsulfoxide
(DMSO), hexamethylphosphoramide (HMPA), N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP),
tetramethylurea (TMU), triethylphosphate (TEP), and trimethylphosphate (TMP) are
considered good solvents for PVDF [8] allowing the solvent casting of PVDF. Among
these solvents, DMSO, DMF and TEP present distinct values of dielectric constant,
providing a good set of materials for the main objective and novelty of the present
investigation: analyze the effect of the different solvent on the processing of PVDF and
PVDF/zeolite composites and analyze qualitatively and quantitatively the encapsulation
of the solvents within the zeolite structure and their contribution to the overall electrical
response of the composites.

microporous material. Porous materials are classified according to their porous size in

3.2.2. Preparation of ?-PVDF and ?-PVDF/NaY composite films
The ?-PVDF and ?-PVDF/NaY films were prepared by solvent casting [17]. For the
preparation of the ?-PVDF films, 1.0 g of PVDF was mixed with 4 mL of solvent
(DMF, TEP or DMSO) during 1 h at 100 rpm and spread into a glass. For the
production of ?-PVDF/NaY composite films, 16 % weight of zeolite were added to 4
mL of solvent (DMF, TEP or DMSO) and placed in ultrasound bath during 6 h for
homogenization. After that, 1 g of PVDF was added and mixed during 1 h at 100 rpm
before spreading it into a glass. After these steps, films were melted in an oven kept at a
controlled temperature for 10 min. The oven temperatures were 210, 256 and 230 ºC for
the films prepared with DMF, TEP and DMSO, respectively. In this way, the difference
between the boiling point of the solvent and the temperature at which the film is melted
is maintained. These conditions guarantee the isothermal crystallization of PVDF.
Finally, the films were removed from the oven and cooled down at room temperature.
The thickness of the films was around 40-50 µm.

responsible for the dielectric constant increase. On the other hand, the motion of polar
molecules on the presence of an electrical field leads, directly, to an increase of

The introduction of NaY zeolite within the PVDF matrix induces two changes on the
behavior of the electrical conductivity [38]. First, there is an increase on the
conductivity values of the composites when compared with the neat polymer. Further,
the conductivity behavior is divided into two regimes. The first regime is linear and the
conductivity value is lower than the conductivity values of the second regime. The
second one is also linear, but with higher values of conductivity. The intersection
voltage separating these two regimes of the I-V curves is called “break voltage” [42].
This voltage is enough to reach the activation energy associated to the motion of the
cations, i.e., is strong enough to break the interaction between ions and the zeolite
framework and so they becomes free to move into zeolite cavities, increasing the
conductivity of the composites. Since the “breaking voltage” just depends on the nature

composite. Due to the lower dielectric constant of TEP, it does not support cation
mobility and therefore a higher activation energy is needed for the initiation of the
second conductivity process. Consequently, the “breaking voltage” of this composite is
higher than 10 V and so only the first linear regime of conductivity is observed.

3.4. Conclusion
Highly flexible PVDF/NaY composite films were prepared by solvent casting with three
different solvents: DMF, DMSO and TEP. All the samples maintain the non-polar ?-
phase and the typical spherulitic structure of PVDF and the presence of NaY cause a
decrease of the spherulitic size. The presence of NaY also induces an increase of the
dielectric constant in all composites when compared with pure ?-PVDF due to confined
mobility of sodium cations on zeolite structure. The dielectric constant of the solvent
used also influences the dielectric and conductivity response of the composite films,
since its molecules are encapsulated into the zeolite cavities. Solvent molecules change
the distribution of intra zeolite cations and so the activation energy and the Coulomb
attraction between cations and zeolite framework. On the other hand, the solvent polar
molecules are oriented on the presence of an electrical field. Due these facts, higher
dielectric constant solvent leads to a higher dielectric constant response composite. The
composite prepared with DMSO present the higher dielectric constant followed by
DMF and TEP. Two regimes on I-V curve are observed for DMF and DMSO
composites, however, the last one presents a lower “breaking voltage” value. The
second regime on TEP composites is not observed probably due the too higher
“breaking voltage” value observed.

4.1. Introduction
Poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) is a semi-crystalline polymer with the largest piezo
and ferroelectric responses among polymers [1]. The piezoelectric ability of the material
to convert mechanical into electrical energy and vice versa allows important
applications in the areas of sensors and actuators [2]. The electroactive properties of the
material are intimately related to the presence of some of the crystalline phases of
PVDF, in particular, the ?- and the ?-phases. The ?-phase can be obtain by mechanical
stretching of the ?-phase (non-polar phase), by applying a strong poling electrical field
or by crystallizing from solution with either dimethylformamide (DMF) or
dimethylacetamide (DMA) at temperatures below 70 ºC [3, 4]. The later method results,
nevertheless, in highly porous and fragile films [5]. On the other hand, the
crystallization or annealing at temperatures close to the melting temperature of PVDF
promotes the development of the ?-phase [6].
Together to these processing strategies, the nucleation of both electroactive phases, ? or
?-phases, can be also achieved by micro and nanoparticle inclusions in the polymer
matrix [7-9]. This strategy shows several advantages with respect to the aforementioned
ones: a) new functionalities can be added to the polymer, such as magnetoelectric [10]
and electro-optical responses [11], among others; b) it does not imply further processing
steps such as stretching or the application of high electric fields; c) it allows the
preparation of thin and thick samples and samples with different shapes and formats by
techniques such as spin-coating [12], electrospinning [13], dip-coatig, etc and d) it
facilitates integration into micro and nanodevices [14].
Nanoclays, layered alumina-silicates that consist on very thin layers usually bounded to
together with counter-ions [15], are one of the most recent and interesting nanoparticles
used for this purpose [9, 11, 16]. In this case, the nucleation of the electroactive phase of
PVDF is also strongly affected by the processing conditions, such as the processing
temperature [11]. In this way, when the PVDF/clay composite is prepared from the melt
at 200 ºC it crystallizes in the ?-phase, whereas the ?-phase is obtained when the
composite is crystallized from temperatures below 200 ºC [11]. Considering that this
effect is associated to surface interactions between the nanofillers and the polymer, it is
interesting to investigate whether the effect will occur in PVDF composites with
particles that share similar physical and chemical surface properties than the clays, such

as zeolites. Further, whereas clays show a layered crystalline structure with a swelling
and shrinking behaviour as water is absorbed or removed [17], zeolites show a rigid
three-dimensional framework of tetrahedral SiO4 and AlO4 primary building units,
forming channels and cavities with sizes in the range of molecular dimensions [18].
This intricate channel structure makes them an interesting material for shape selectivity
and, differently from the clays, foreign molecules can move freely in and out the zeolite
pores without affecting the zeolite framework. Furthermore, zeolites can be used to
produce stable materials with respect to heat, steam and chemical attacks, making them
suitable for a wide range of applications [19].
It has been proven that PVDF/Y zeolite composites prepared from the melt at 210 ºC
originate highly flexible films with increased dielectric response, being the PVDF/NaY
the one with the most interesting dielectric properties [20]. The dielectric constant of
these composites increases with respect to the pure polymer and depends on Si/Al ratio
and zeolite content. An increase on the composite electrical conductivity is also
observed associated to an intrazeolite charge transport. However, the crystallization of
PVDF polymer occurs on ?-phase [20, 21]. The present work shows the novel,
important and interesting fact that the processing temperature influences the
crystallization phase of the polymer, leading to PVDF/NaY zeolite composites with the
polymer in one of its electroactive phases. Further, the electroactive phase is obtained
without the need of a stretching process, which allows easier processing of the material
and fabrication of devices. In this way, the combination of the electroactivity of the
polymer matrix and the cage structure of the zeolites results in composites with large
potential for sensor and actuator [22] and energy harvesting and storage technologies
[23], among others.

4.2. Experimental
Composite films of PVDF and NaY zeolite with zeolite concentrations of 4, 16, 24 and
32 wt% and with a thickness of ~ 50 µm were prepared by spreading a solution of
PVDF (Solef 1010 from Solvay, Belgium) in N,N-dimethyl formamide (DMF, Merck)
solvent on a glass slide. Previously, the zeolite was dried at 120 ºC for 2 h added to 4
mL of DMF and placed in an ultrasound bath for 4 h. 1 g of PVDF in powder form was
added to this suspension and dissolved with the help of a magnetic stirrer (JPSelecta,
Agimatic-E). After being melted at 190 ºC or at 210 ºC for 10 min, the film was
removed from the oven and cooled down at room temperature.
The NaY zeolites used for the preparation of the composites were obtained from Zeolyst
International (Conshohocken, PA 19428-2240 USA) with the following characteristics
(CBV 100): Si/Al ratio: 2.83; Nominal Cation Form: Sodium; Na2O weight: 13%; Unit
cell size: 24.65 A; Surface Area: 900 m 2 /g.
The microstructure of the composite matrix and the dispersion of the NaY zeolite was
analysed by Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) surface images taken from the top
side of the as prepared samples with a JEOL JSM-5410 scanning microscope. The
samples were previously coated with a thin gold layer using a sputter coater (Polaron,
model SC502).
The phase of the polymer within the composite samples was analysed by Fourier
Transformed Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR) (Spectrum 100, Attenuate Total Reflectance
mode) in the range between 650 and 4000 cm ?1
, on 32 scans. The error associated to the
phase content evaluation is ± 2%.
Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) was performed in samples of ~6 mg on a
Mettler Toledo DSC 823 apparatus under a nitrogen atmosphere at a heating rate of 10

4.4. Conclusion
Composite films of PVDF with NaY zeolite were successfully prepared by solvent
casting, melting and recrystallization. It was demonstrated that the melting temperature
can affect the PVDF crystallization phase. In this way, the composites prepared after
melting at 190ºC crystallize in the ?-phase, while the ones prepared after melting at
210ºC crystallize in the ?-phase. The composites show a higher thermal stability and the
presence of water molecules encapsulated in the zeolite structure. Both effects are
dependent on zeolite content and composite preparation temperature. The presence of
ions to stabilize the zeolites structure causes an increase of dielectric response of the
composite due to the confined mobility into the zeolites cavities and to interfacial
effects. The presence of these ions in zeolites is also responsible for the existence of
non-linear I-V curves with two regimes separated by the break voltage in which a strong
increase of conductivity takes place due to the resale of the ion-zeolite interaction. The
presence of trapped water molecules as well as the electroactive phase of the polymer
contribute to the increase of the values of both the dielectric constant and the
conductivity.

5.1. Introduction
Electroactive poly(vinylidene fluoride)/zeolite composites are interesting materials for
advanced applications due to the electroactive properties of the polymer matrix [1, 2]
and the characteristics of the nanoporous zeolite structures which allow tailoring optical,
magnetic and electric properties by suitable synthesis strategies and the possibility to
host specific guest molecules within the framework [3-6]. Poly(vinylidene fluoride),
PVDF, shows excellent mechanical properties, high thermal and chemical stability and
the strongest piezo-, pyro and ferroelectric responses among polymers [2], allowing a
variety of technological applications such as sensors and actuators. This semi-crystalline
polymer is also known for its polymorphism. It can be obtained in polar (?, ? and ?)
and non-polar (?) phases by the variation of crystallization conditions [7], which
include control of crystallization temperature [8], mechanical stretching [9] or the
introduction of specific fillers [10-12].
The dielectric response of PVDF is one of the key parameters for applications. Neat
PVDF shows a dielectric constant between 6 and 12 at room temperature, depending of
the polymorph, and two main relaxation processes. The first relaxation process is
known as the ?-relaxation. It occurs at low temperatures and it is associated to
cooperative segmental motions within the main chains of the amorphous regions during
the glass transition of the polymer. The second relaxation, known as the ?-relaxation,
appears at higher temperatures and it is associated to molecular motions within the
crystalline fraction of the polymer [13-16] or in the crystal-amorphous interphase
region, [17]. It has been shown that poling the electroactive phase of PVDF, an
important step for using the material for sensor applications, does not affect the
relaxation temperatures of PVDF, the ?-relaxation appearing around -35 ºC and the ?-
relaxation above 40ºC, at 1Hz [18].
Zeolites are microporous crystalline aluminosilicates formed by the coordination of

uniform and molecular-sized pores makes them interesting for catalysis [20], adsorption
[21] and ion exchange [22] applications. Together with these applications with the
zeolites in powder form, these materials have been used separation membranes and
membrane reactors in the form of films [23]. The dielectric properties of zeolites are
influenced by several factors, such as the nature of the cations, their size and charge, the
lattice structure and the degree of hydration [24].

One of the most interesting and used zeolite structures is the NaY-zeolite. It shows
interesting electrical properties ascribed to two main processes: a low-temperature
process associated to local motions (dielectric relaxation) and a high-temperature
process associated to translational motions (diffusion/conductivity) [25]. At low
frequency, the dielectric relaxation process is assigned to a Maxwell-Wagner-Sillars
process that is shifted to higher frequency as temperature increases. The latter relaxation
at the highest frequencies, is ascribed to the local motions of cations in the ?-cage
and/or rotational fluctuations of water molecules [26, 27]. However, the large mobility
of the exchangeable cations (local polarization in the supercages and long-range
migration over larger distances) results in a high electrical ionic conductivity [25, 26].
The influence of zeolite content in the dielectric relaxation and electrical conductivity of
zeolite-polymer composites has been scarcely reported. In particular, it has been shown
that ionic relaxation dominates the ac conductivity behavior of zeolite – conductive
polymer composites [28, 29].
Previous studies on PVDF-zeolites composites demonstrate that the presence of NaY
zeolite in the PVDF matrix induces an increase of the room temperature dielectric
response of the polymer associated to confined ion mobility in the zeolite cavities and to
a Maxwell-Wagner-Sillars polarization [30]. Further, the presence of NaY zeolite can
also induce the ?-phase crystallization of the polymer, leading to piezoelectric
composites [31]. In this way, PVDF/zeolite composites appear as a very promising set
of materials with a wide range of potential applications. The electrical behavior of these
materials is critical for the development of applications and therefore deserved a deep
investigation in order to to assess the effect of nanoparticle contents and polymer-zeolite
interactions on the ion and dipole mobility.
In the present work, PVDF/ NaY zeolite composite films with different NaY zeolite
contents were prepared by solvent casting. The microstructure and crystalline phase
were evaluated by scanning electron microscopy and Fourier transform infrared
spectroscopy, respectively. The dielectric relaxation spectrum and electrical
conductivity behavior were evaluated and the the electric modulus formalism was
applied at high temperatures in order get insight on the origin of the electrical response
of the composite.

5.2. Experimental
5.2.1. Sample preparation
Composite films of PVDF (Solef 1010) with different NaY zeolite contents were
prepared by solvent casting [30]. The zeolite was obtained from Zeolyst International
(Conshohocken, PA 19428-2240 USA) in powder form with the following
characteristics (CBV 100): Si/Al ratio = 2.83 with 7.76 % of sodium content (which
corresponds to 47.2 sodium for unit cell) and a specific surface area of 787 m 2 /g.
The zeolite was dried at 120 ºC for 2h and added to N,N-dimethyl formamide (DMF)
solvent. The suspension was then placed in an ultrasound bath for 4 h for
homogenization. After this period, 1 g of PVDF polymer was added to the zeolite
suspension and dissolved under magnetic stirring. Finally, the material was spread on a
glass slide and the solvent was evaporated in an oven at 190ºC for 10 min (at this
temperature the polymer is in the liquid state). In this way, homogeneous composite
films with a thickness of ~ 50 µm were prepared with different zeolite contents (wt/wt
%): 0 (PVDF), 4 (PVDF/NaY4% ) and 16 % (PVDF/NaY16%).

5.4. Conclusion
Structural and dielectric properties of PVDF/zeolite composite changes significantly
with respect to pure PVDF. Good dispersion of NaY zeolite particles was assessed by
SEM, although some clustering was observed in the composite with the highest
nanoparticle content. The introduction of the zeolite particles nucleates the
crystallization of PVDF in the electroactive ? phase and modifies the spherulite size.
Broadband dielectric relaxation spectroscopy shows two regions in the relaxation map
of the composites, the low-temperature one dominated by dipolar relaxations both in
PVDF and in the zeolite particles, with small influence of one phase on the behavior of
the other. The high temperature side of the spectrum is dominated by ionic conductivity
and interfacial polarization. The presence of the zeolite particles introduce new
discontinuity surfaces and increases the MWS contribution that is predominant at low
frequencies with respect to ohmic contribution to permittivity as detected in the ac
conductivity plots while producing a specific MWS relaxation process due to polymer-
zeolite interfaces.

6.1. Introduction
The mixing of polymers and clays has been widely investigated in recent years mainly
due the mechanical reinforcement effect of the latter. The main goal has been to replace
traditional fibre reinforced composites due to improved strength and stiffness stability,
thermal and barrier properties and flame retardant behaviour of the clay composites[1-
3]. One interesting polymer for composites production is poly(vinylidene fluoride),
PVDF, due to its remarkable electroative properties and therefore its suitability for
sensor and actuator applications. Furthermore, PVDF films present high flexibility, high
mechanical resistance, dimensional stability, lightness, moldability, low cost production
and low mechanical and acoustic impedance [4]. Depending on the processing
conditions PVDF, with a chemical formula (CH2-CF2)n, can crystallise in at least four
different phases: ?, ?, ? and ? [5, 6]. The ?-phase, that has an alternating s-trans and s-
gauche C-C bonds, is the most stable when the material is cooled from the melt and
therefore the most commonly obtained [5]. The ?-phase, with all C-C bonds in the s-
trans conformation (TTTT), is the one that presents the best electroactive piezoelectric
and pyroelectric properties and is commonly obtained by mechanical stretching of the
?-phase [7] or by the addition of selected nanoparticles [8, 9]. The ?-phase is, as the ?-
phase, electrically active. However, due the presence of a g-gauche bond every fourth
repeat units of C-C band (T3GT3 ), this effect if weaker when compared with ?-phase.
?-phase can be obtained by crystallization from the melt or solution casting at
temperatures near the melt temperature of the ?-phase. The ? ? solid state phase
transformation also can occur by annealing at temperatures close to melt temperature
[10].
In the last years, the literature reports some studies where organically modified clays
show the ability to induce, by melt intercalation or solution casting, the crystallization
of the electroactive ?-phase of PVDF [11-14] and, in a few studies, the induction of a
crystalline ?-phase [14, 15].
The distribution, intercalation and exfoliation of organically modified silicates prepared
from Cloisite and Montmorillonite clays has been investigated and it is concluded that
the trend of PVDF to crystallize in the ?-phase is higher in organically modified clays
when compared with unmodified clays [11]. In all cases, the full ?-phase crystallization
is obtained by inclusion of an amount of clay higher than 1.5 wt%.[16]. The full ?-phase
crystallization of PVDF has also been achieved for lower clay contents, of the order of

In the present work, the main problems that exist in the processing of electroactive
PVDF through the nucleation with clays are addressed. It is shown that it is possible to
prepare PVDF/clay composite in the ?-phase with low clay contents, without any
organic treatment and with a low consumption of material. Moreover, the material
presents increased transmittance in the visible range, making it appropriate for optical
applications. It is also shown that the material can be poled and the d33 piezoelectric
coefficient has been measured as a function of the clay and the ?-phase contents. A
systematic study of the isothermal crystallization kinetics of PVDF with unmodified
clays with the main goal of elucidating the influence of clay content in the
crystallization kinetics and therefore in the nucleation of the electroactive ?-phase of
PVDF was also performed. Finally, it is shown that different clays can be used in order
to achieve the electroactive polymer phase.

6.2. Experimental
PVDF/clay composites with an average thickness of 50 µm were prepared by spreading
a solution of 1.0 g of PVDF powder (Solef 1010) with a suspension of montmorillonite
K10 (Aldrich) in 4 mL of N,N-dimethyl formamide (DMF) in a glass slide. Previously,
the suspension of montmorillonite and DMF was homogenized by placing it in an
ultrasound bath for 4h before the polymer was added and dissolved with a magnetic
stirrer. After this process the composite is typically melted at 210ºC and recrystallised to
room temperature [23]. Since the clay can suffer structural modifications at this
temperatures [24, 25], six films with a clay concentration of 0.50 wt% were prepared at
temperatures between 170 ºC and 220 ºC in order to study the effect of the polymer
melting temperature during composite preparation. The effect of clay concentration on
the electroactive phase content was further studied in films with 0.10, 0.25 and 0.50
wt% of montmorillonite. The effect of different clay structures was studied by
incorporating an amount of 0.50 % of kaolinite (from North of Portugal) and laponite
(Laport Industries Ltd) into the polymer matrix by the same procedure explained

The lithium battery industry represents the largest segment of the industry of portable
batteries for computers, cell phones and cameras. However these batteries still have

7.3. PVDF/aluminosilicate composites used for
biomedical applications
Novel materials are continuously developed with the objective of being used in
biomedical applications. Among these, polymer based materials have confirmed to be a
good biomaterials choice in tissue engineering applications, smart prostheses and
sensors and controlled drug delivery, among others [9, 10]. In particular the inclusion of
zeolites allows increasing functional properties and controlled drug release [11].
7.3.1. Cell growth membrane
The potential of electroactive polymers has been recognized for biomedical
applications. Due to its ability to convert mechanical, thermal or magnetic signals into
electrical ones, electroactive polymers can be used as smart scaffolds to stimulate cell
growth and compatibility [12]. Once fillers introduction into the polymer matrix can
modify biomaterial-cell interaction and/or create novel bioactivity or even suppression
of biocompatibility [13, 14], composites based on poly(vinylidene fluoride), PVDF,
have been evaluated with respect to their biological response. Cell viability and
proliferation were performed in vitro both with Mesenchymal Stem Cells differentiated
to osteoblasts and Human Fibroblast Foreskin [15]. In-vivo tests were also performed
using six week-old C57Bl/6 mice. It was concluded that zeolite and clay composites are
biocompatible materials promoting cell response and not showing in vivo pro-
inflammatory effects, which renders both of them attractive for biological applications
and tissue engineering, opening interesting perspectives to development of scaffolds
from these composites[15].

8. Conclusions and future work
Conclusions and future work
Ana Catarina Lopes 159
8.1. Conclusions
Electroactive polymer composites are extensively developed in order to approach
materials properties to specific applications. This work was devoted to the development
of poly(vinylidene fluorite)/aluminosilicate composites due to the strong electroactivity
of the polymer matrix, being the main representative of the family of polymers with the
largest piezo- and ferroelectric response, and to the versatility of the aluminoslicate
fillers, allowing suitable modifications in shape, size and Si/Al ratio, among others, for
achieving specific applications demands.
In this way, PVDF/zeolite composites were successfully prepared by solvent casting
and melt crystallization. A study of the structural, thermal and electrical properties of
the PVDF composites prepared with different framework zeolite types (LTL, LTA,
FAU and MFI), different polymer solvents (DMF, DMSO, TEP) and different zeolite
(NaY) concentrations (4, 16, 24 and 32 wt.%) was performed.
A good distribution of the fillers was obtained in all films that maintain the spherulitic
structure of neat PVDF as well as its mechanical properties. Further, the degradation
temperature of PVDF is not significantly affected by the inclusion of the fillers It was
verified that zeolite introduction affects the electrical properties of the polymer and the
polymer phase crystallization. The presence of ions stabilizing the zeolite structure
causes an increase of the dielectric response of the composite due to its confined
mobility into the zeolites cavities and to interfacial effects associated to Maxwell-
Wagner-Sillers polarization. These ions are also responsible for the presence of non-
linear I-V curves where two regimes are identified separated by a break voltage at
which a strong increase of the electrical conductivity takes place. Zeolites structures
with lower Si/Al ratios are associated to higher number of ions, resulting in a higher
dielectric and electrical response.
The dielectric relaxation of the composites shows a low temperature region dominated
by dipolar relaxations of the PVDF and relaxations ascribed to the zeolites, while the
high temperature side of the spectrum is dominated by ionic conductivity. The presence
of zeolite particles induces new discontinuity surfaces and increases the Maxwell-
Wagner-Sillers contribution.
Zeolites with low Si/Al ratios show the ability to completely nucleate the electroactive
phase of the polymer due to strong electrostatic interactions related to the cation

just 0.50 wt.% clay content is enough to completely crystallize the polymer in the

The negatively charged delaminated clays and zeolite structures interact with the dipolar

8.2. Future work
PVDF/zeolite and PVDF/clay composites revealed to be promising materials for
technological applications. In this way, it is interesting to study their upscale production
in order to obtain similar electrical and optical properties by, e.g., extrusion processes,
avoiding the use of solvents.
In a similar way, the upscaling of the porous membranes has to be studied.
Further investigation has to be devoted to the effect of the variation of the ion type used
to stabilize the zeolite/clay in the electrical and optical properties of the composites.
Finally, molecules can be encapsulated in the zeolite pores to further tailor composite
response to specific applications.
Finally, materials can be readily used for the development of environmental and bio
sensors that have to be fully characterize with respect to their performance.
